docs.lead_paragraph: Prices paid to producers in January rose at the fastest pace in more than a decade, pushed up by rising energy and auto costs, the Labor Department said today in a report suggesting more evidence of inflation than expected. Overall producer prices climbed 1.6 percent, the largest rise since January 1990, surpassing forecasts of a 0.5 percent increase. This compared with a 0.1 percent decline in wholesale prices in December.

headline.main: Producer Prices Are Up Sharply; Jobless Claims Also Higher

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports producer prices climbed 1.6 percent, largest rise since January 1990, surpassing forecasts of 0.5 percent increase and compared with 0.1 percent decline in wholesale prices in December; car prices posted their fastest increase since October 1986, rising 3.5 percent; pharmaceutical costs climbed 1.2 percent and capital equipment prices rose 0.7 percent; food prices were up 1.6 percent; department reports number of Americans seeking jobless benefits for first time rose by 21,000, to seasonally adjusted 402,000, in week ended Feb 15; four-week moving average rose to 394,750, increase of 4,750 from previous week; Conference Board says its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.1 percent in January, after 0.2 percent rise in December; board's chief economist Ken Goldstein comments; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: Prices paid to producers in January rose at the fastest pace in more than a decade, pushed up by rising energy and auto costs, the Labor Department said today in a report suggesting more evidence of inflation than expected.    Overall producer prices...

docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has come up short so far in his efforts to win savings from the city's unions, told city commissioners yesterday that they might have to cut their budgets further if the unions balked at new concessions. The mayor is counting on $600 million in union savings to balance next year's budget, money that could be saved by asking city workers to pay part of their health insurance costs, instituting a longer workweek, or creating a less generous pension plan for future workers, among other ways. But the suggestions have gone nowhere so far.

headline.main: Friendly Budget Talk, an Implicit Threat

docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg is counting on $600 million in union savings to balance next year's budget and tells city commissioners that they might have to cut their budgets further; sends clear message that if unions do not come up with savings, services will suffer and jobs could be lost; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has come up short so far in his efforts to win savings from the city's unions, told city commissioners yesterday that they might have to cut their budgets further if the unions balked at new concessions.    The mayor...

docs.lead_paragraph: Connecticut's attorney general sued Yale-New Haven Hospital today, accusing it of denying needy patients access to millions of dollars in donations intended to provide free hospital beds for the poor. In a civil suit filed in State Superior Court in Hartford, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal accused the hospital of hoarding $37 million in donations commonly called ''free-bed funds'' and failing to meet a legal duty to properly distribute the money.

headline.main: Connecticut Sues Yale-New Haven Hospital, Saying It Hoarded Money Donated for the Poor

docs.abstract: Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal sues Yale-New Haven Hospital, accusing it of denying needy patients access to donated money intended to provide free hospital beds for poor; hospital denies charges and points to its long history of meeting needs of patients and community (M)
docs.snippet: Connecticut's attorney general sued Yale-New Haven Hospital today, accusing it of denying needy patients access to millions of dollars in donations intended to provide free hospital beds for the poor.     In a civil suit filed in State Superior Court...

docs.lead_paragraph: Jésica Santillán waited three years for the wrong heart. Today, she may have received the right one, nearly two weeks after Duke University Hospital mistakenly gave her a heart and lung transplant from a donor with an incompatible blood type. This morning, a family anonymously donated the needed organs, giving the fading Ms. Santillán a second chance.

headline.main: Girl in Donor Mix-Up Undergoes 2nd Transplant

docs.abstract: Jesica Santillan undergoes second heart and lung transplant nearly two weeks after Duke University Hospital mistakenly gives her organs from donor with incompatible blood type; incredible stress of first botched transplant left her unconscious; her doctors give 17-year-old only 50-50 chance of surviving; doctors not connected to her case offer bleaker assessment, noting that one-year survival rate for transplanting heart and both lungs together is ordinarily about 60 percent; say second transplants are done in less than 1 percent of cases, and rarely are they done because of blood-type mix-ups; officials at Duke University Hospital admit to making several mistakes when doctors inserted wrong organs during original transplant; say chief surgeon 'falsely assumed' that blood match had been confirmed; spokesman for Duke says university would make public internal review and chronology of events in case; document might explain why Duke waited for week to disclose that girl was victim of mistake; photos; diagram (L)
docs.snippet: Jésica Santillán waited three years for the wrong heart.    Today, she may have received the right one, nearly two weeks after Duke University Hospital mistakenly gave her a heart and lung transplant from a donor with an incompatible blood type....

byline.original: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN with LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: After Congress failed to create a national health care plan, Medicaid became the default solution to the crisis of the growing number of uninsured Americans. Expanding Medicaid was a success in terms of meeting a critical need. But the price is now staggering strapped state governments. The Bush administration is responding with an offer of modest help, essentially a loan against future Medicaid payments -- but there is a catch. To get the aid, states must agree to radical changes in their Medicaid plans, which will eventually take the federal government off the hook for some -- and perhaps much -- of its share of the costs. At bottom, Washington wants to limit its long-term responsibility for the only kind of health program many Americans can afford. And it's planning to bribe the governors to go along. This is outrageously unfair. Any federal aid should be made available to all states, even those that want to maintain the current structure of their Medicaid programs.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Bush administration is letting itself off hook for much of cost of funding Medicaid in long run by shifting responsibility to states when it should be trying to find ways to keep people who would otherwise be uninsured from falling out of Medicaid program; suggests that if prescription drug coverage were provided for all Medicare recipients, it would relieve Medicaid of paying costs for elderly poor
docs.snippet: After Congress failed to create a national health care plan, Medicaid became the default solution to the crisis of the growing number of uninsured Americans. Expanding Medicaid was a success in terms of meeting a critical need. But the price is now...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said today that he wanted the nation's governors to endorse President Bush's proposal for sweeping changes in Medicaid when they meet here next week. But state officials said they had many questions about the proposal, and some expressed reservations.

headline.main: All Governors To Be Asked To Back Bush On Medicaid

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Tommy G Thompson says he wants all of nation's governors to endorse Pres Bush's proposal for sweeping changes in Medicaid at upcoming annual National Governors Association conference in Washington, DC; some state officials are skeptical over proposal, which would give states vast new power to expand, reduce or eliminate benefits for millions of low-income people, including many who are elderly or disabled (M)
docs.snippet: Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said today that he wanted the nation's governors to endorse President Bush's proposal for sweeping changes in Medicaid when they meet here next week.    But state officials said they had...

docs.lead_paragraph: Along the hallways of the Indianapolis Convention Center, Willis McGahee is moving more slowly than everybody else. He insists he lost his limp days ago, but his gait still holds a limp's echo. His pace makes people stare. Everybody wants to know how his left knee is holding up, the knee in which he tore three ligaments during the Fiesta Bowl against Ohio State on Jan. 3. Everybody wants to know what it feels like to go from a potential top five pick to a question mark.

headline.main: Here's a Franchise Player In Search of a Franchise

docs.snippet: Along the hallways of the Indianapolis Convention Center, Willis McGahee is moving more slowly than everybody else. He insists he lost his limp days ago, but his gait still holds a limp's echo.    His pace makes people stare. Everybody wants to know...

docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, struggling to control a ballooning budget deficit, state legislators in Arizona reduced funds for the arts. This year, facing an even larger deficit, they are proposing a simpler approach: cutting arts financing altogether. A legislative committee has recommended eliminating the state arts agency in Arizona and its $5.1 million annual budget. It has also recommended that a $7 million fund established as an endowment for arts programs be dissolved, so the money can be used for other purposes.

headline.main: Some States Propose End to Arts Spending

docs.abstract: Arizona, New Jersey, Missouri and other states propose cutting spending on the arts in face of decline in tax revenues and weak economy, prompting arts advocacy groups nationwide to begin what is likely to be long and difficult campaign to restore at lest some financing; economic downturn also means that private funds are harder to come by; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Last year, struggling to control a ballooning budget deficit, state legislators in Arizona reduced funds for the arts. This year, facing an even larger deficit, they are proposing a simpler approach: cutting arts financing altogether.     A...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE New York office of BBDO Worldwide makes a belated entrance this week into one of the advertising industry's more lucrative categories with the creation of a division dedicated to pitching prescription drugs directly to consumers. The new unit, called BBDO Health Work, opened Tuesday with Anne Devereux, a longtime health care industry executive, as president. But the move into the so-called pharmacare arena by BBDO New York, best known for its entertaining campaigns for FedEx, Pepsi-Cola and Visa, does not come at the most propitious time.

headline.main: BBDO Worldwide enters the lucrative category of marketing prescription drugs to consumers.

docs.abstract: New York office of BBDO Worldwide makes belated entrance into one of advertising industry's most lucrative categories with creation of division dedicated to pitching prescription drugs directly to consumers; Anne Devereux is president of new unit, called BBDO Health Work; competition is fierce, as most other big agencies already pursue prescription drug advertising and many other smaller shops devote their efforts primarily to health care advertising; BBDO president Andrew Robertson comments; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THE New York office of BBDO Worldwide makes a belated entrance this week into one of the advertising industry's more lucrative categories with the creation of a division dedicated to pitching prescription drugs directly to consumers.    The new unit,...

docs.lead_paragraph: A FEDERAL appeals court ruling issued in New York this month could crucially weaken the multibillion-dollar managed care industry, the H.M.O. trade association contends. Spokesmen for employers said they were concerned that the decision could result in higher costs for health care. But a spokesman for the American Medical Association hailed the decision, saying it meant that insurance companies would be held accountable if patients were harmed by delays and denials of approval for care.

headline.main: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A court says insurance companies should be accountable for damage to a patient's health.

docs.abstract: American Association of Health Plans says Federal appeals court ruling issued in New York on Feb 11 could crucially weaken multibillion-dollar managed care industry; American Medical Association hails decision, saying it means that insurance companies will be held accountable if patients are harmed by delays and denials of approval for care; ruling said that Vytra Healthcare could not invoke federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act to prevent Bonnie Cicio, widow of Carmine Cicio, from suing Vytra in New York State court, accusing Vytra of medical malpractice; Cicio died of myeloma in 1988; Vytra rejected Cicio doctor's order for double-strength transplant of bone marrow stem cells, contending that treatment is experimental and thus not covered by his contract (Market Place column) (M)
